title: Rob Reiner Remembered: One of Hollywoodâ€™s Great Comic Voices Meets a Tragic End
description: Itâ€™s a sad day in Hollywood â€” an unthinkable, upsetting and all-around shocking day â€” when filmmaker Rob Reiner and his wife Michelle could have bee
body:
Itâ€™s a sad day in Hollywood â€” an unthinkable, upsetting and all-around shocking day â€” when filmmaker Rob Reiner and his wife Michelle could have been stabbed to death in their own home, allegedly by someone so close.

	The particulars are hazy, the initial reports nearly impossible to wrap oneâ€™s head around. Itâ€™s clear that in the days ahead, the scandal will likely overshadow the career of one of the industryâ€™s most beloved directors, a man widely admired for his work, his activism and his contagiously optimistic spirit. In the â€œ100 Best Comedy Movies of All Timeâ€ list recently published by Variety, Reiner was responsible for no fewer than three of the entries.
	

	Iâ€™m not exaggerating in the slightest when I say that among American studio talents, I consider Rob Reiner the best director never to have been nominated for Best Director. Just look at his credits. The guy was the Billy Wilder of our generation: a filmmaker with an instinct for comedy who could operate across genres, making films with big, larger-than-life characters you recognized instantly and felt youâ€™d known your whole life.


	Reiner wasnâ€™t a stylist like Martin Scorsese â€” the filmmaking idol on whom â€œThis Is Spinal Tapâ€ â€œdirectorâ€ Marty DiBergi was based (and for whom he finally got to act in â€œThe Wolf of Wall Street,â€ playing Leonardo DiCaprioâ€™s dad). He wasnâ€™t a visionary technological innovator like Robert Zemeckis â€” the performance-capture pioneer who took â€œThe Polar Express,â€ a project Reiner had initiated with Tom Hanks, and made motion-picture history with it.
	

	But he made at least six hall-of-fame films, practically one after another over the course of an 11-year run (a number forever associated with him). Reiner kicked off his directorial career with the endlessly quotable, mock rock doc â€œThis Is Spinal Tap,â€ hitting new comedic heights straight out of the gate in 1984 by poking fun at an absurd (yet plausible) heavy metal band. Two years later, he delivered that greatest of coming-of-age films, â€œStand by Meâ€ â€” a movie featuring kids who really act like kids, facing the notion of mortality for the first time.

	Then came what Iâ€™ve long considered to be my desert-island movie â€” as in, the one film Iâ€™d save if I was banished somewhere with a projector, a screen and a single print Iâ€™m certain Iâ€™d never get tired of watching: â€œThe Princess Bride.â€ More on that in a minute. I was exactly the right age when that head-in-the-clouds, heart-on-the-sleeve postmodern fairy tale was released, but grown-ups at the time went crazy for his down-to-earth follow-up, â€œWhen Harry Met Sallyâ€¦,â€ which almost singlehandedly revived the romantic comedy genre.

	Right there, youâ€™ve got four movies that defined the â€™80s, and we havenâ€™t even gotten to his two most acclaimed credits: â€œA Few Good Men,â€ the decadeâ€™s most-quoted (and surely also its most-rewatched) courtroom drama, in which Jack Nicholson bellows, â€œYou canâ€™t handle the truth!â€ at Tom Cruiseâ€™s self-righteous military lawyer. Reiner reteamed with screenwriter Aaron Sorkin three years later on â€œThe American President,â€ another irresistible Hollywood romance, this one with a backbone idealistic enough to inspire â€œThe West Wing.â€

	I know Iâ€™m not alone in adoring all six of those movies, though itâ€™s telling that none are the type where one immediately thinks of the man calling â€œaction!â€ Sorkinâ€™s fingerprints are all over the latter two. â€œThis Is Spinal Tapâ€ is commonly associated with Christopher Guest, who went on to make several more improv-driven mockumentaries in the same mold. Nora Ephron often gets credit for â€œWhen Harry Met Sallyâ€¦,â€ though the script was informed by where both she and Reiner were in their respective romantic lives at the time.

	If Reiner gets too little credit, itâ€™s because he had the wisdom and grace to subtract himself from the equation â€” by which I mean, when watching a Rob Reiner movie, audiences were never thinking about the director: how this shot was brilliant or that cut was clever. He wanted our attention to be focused on the characters, taking great care to cast each and every role with the absolute right actor, then trusting those performers to bring more than the script dictated to their parts.
	

	There must be a case somewhere in Reinerâ€™s filmography of someone being wrong for the role, but I canâ€™t think of an example (then again, I never saw â€œNorthâ€). Instead, my mind goes to a dozen uncannily inspired choices in â€œThe Princess Brideâ€: From Andre the Giant to Mandy Patinkin to Wallace Shawn, those actors fit their characters like a six-fingered glove (in Guestâ€™s case, at least).

	With â€œThe Princess Bride,â€ Reiner accomplished the tricky task of blending several classic Hollywood genres â€” fairy tale romance, fantasy adventure, swashbuckling action and kid-friendly comedy â€” though the studio wasnâ€™t sure what to make of it at the time. Like â€œThis Is Spinal Tapâ€ before it, it took time for audiences to embrace the film. Rest assured, those two cult favorites eventually found their following, to the extent that Reiner broke one of his own rules and finally made a sequel (â€œSpinal Tap II: The End Continuesâ€) this year.

	You canâ€™t look at a Rob Reiner movie and reverse-engineer the manâ€™s genius the way you can a film by Spielberg or Kubrick (though Iâ€™d argue â€œStand by Meâ€ is a better Stephen King adaptation than â€œThe Shiningâ€). The way I see it, there are three subtle but vital qualities that made Reinerâ€™s movies so appealing.

	First, thereâ€™s the way he worked with actors, inviting them to improvise. That was the basis of â€œSpinal Tapâ€â€™s success, and proved to be an asset throughout his career.

	Second, as the son of Carl Reiner â€” and star of the incredibly successful â€™70s sitcom â€œAll in the Familyâ€ â€” Rob had either inherited or absorbed the principles of comedy, incorporating humor into all his films (itâ€™s my opinion that all Hollywood movies are comedies, to some degree at least, and that this running sense of humor is what sets American cinema apart).

	And third, he worked carefully on the scripts with his writers. Some projects he originated, via his Castle Rock shingle, and others he refined over rigorous brainstorming sessions. Sorkin has often credited Reinerâ€™s process with making â€œA Few Good Menâ€ into the rock-solid film it is. These days, too few studio directors polish their scripts to the same degree, worrying not just about dialogue, but structure, stakes and what makes a character feel real.
	

	It makes sense that Reiner would be strong on those fronts. He met Mel Brooks when he was just four years old. Little Rob grew up at the feet of showbiz legends (his father, Carl, wrote for Sid Caesarâ€™s â€œYour Show of Showsâ€), and he paid his dues, studying theater at UCLA, observing and learning from Norman Lear and directing TV movies before crossing over to film.

	Reinerâ€™s career stagnated somewhat in the 21st century, though he made a very funny, disarmingly intimate portrait of best friend Albert Brooks (no relation to Mel) for HBO two years ago, â€œAlbert Brooks: Defending My Life.â€ And of course, there was this yearâ€™s â€œSpinal Tapâ€ sequel, which features more than a few sidesplitting moments â€” and a few epic cameos from the likes of Paul McCartney and Elton John.

	Can a filmmaker be both beloved and underappreciated at the same time? Rob Reiner was. Thinking of what happened to the 78-year-old mensch and his wife this weekend, one word comes to mind: inconceivable.

title: Rob Reiner, Legendary Comedic Actor and â€˜Princess Brideâ€™ Director, FoundÂ DeadÂ in His Home
description: Rob Reiner, who segued from starring in  â€œAll in the Familyâ€ to directing movies including â€œThis Is Spinal Tap,â€ â€œA Few Good Menâ€ and â€œWhen Harry Me
body:
Rob Reiner, who segued from starring in  â€œAll in the Familyâ€ to directing movies including â€œThis Is Spinal Tap,â€ â€œA Few Good Menâ€ and â€œWhen Harry Met Sallyâ€¦â€ was found dead Sunday afternoon in his Brentwood home alongside his wife Michele Singer. He was 78. 

	The deaths are being investigated as a homicide, according to the LAPD. The couple was reported to have been stabbed to death.


	â€œIt is with profound sorrow that we announce the tragic passing of Michele and Rob Reiner. We are heartbroken by this sudden loss, and we ask for privacy during this unbelievably difficult time,â€ his family said in a statement. 
	

	Reinerâ€™s most recent film was â€œSpinal Tap II: The End Continues,â€ the sequel to the 1984 classic â€œThis Is Spinal Tap.â€Â 

	The son of the noted writer, director and comedian Carl Reiner, he first attracted attention as Michael â€œMeatheadâ€ Stivic, hippie son-in-law of Carroll Oâ€™Connorâ€™s bigoted, blustering blue-collar worker Archie Bunker, during nine seasons of CBSâ€™s topical sitcom. He collected Emmys as best supporting actor in a comedy in 1974 and 1978.

	With credits as a writer on â€œThe Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour,â€ â€œHappy Daysâ€ and â€œAll in the Familyâ€ and a pair of TV movies under his belt, Reiner moved into big screen work as a director, writer and co-star in 1984â€™s â€œThis is Spinal Tap,â€ the cherished, improvisational mockumentary about a thick-headed heavy metal band.

	That project was succeeded during the next decade by a run of box office hits and popular favorites, which demonstrated his uncommon assurance working in a variety of genres. These included â€œStand By Meâ€ (1986), a coming-of-age drama with a youthful cast, adapted from a Stephen King short story; the fantasy â€œThe Princess Brideâ€ (1987); the new-look romantic comedy â€œWhen Harry Met Sallyâ€¦â€ (1989); another King adaptation, the thriller â€œMiseryâ€ (1990); and the Tom Cruise-Jack Nicholson court martial drama â€œA Few Good Menâ€ (1992).
	

	Reiner served as producer of most of his films from 1987 on. That year, he co-founded the production company Castle Rock Entertainment, which released several of his films and such hits as â€œIn the Line of Fire,â€ â€œNeedful Thingsâ€ and â€œMalice.â€ The company was acquired by Turner Broadcasting in 1993.

	Save for the occasional hit like the bittersweet 2007 comedy-drama â€œThe Bucket Listâ€ with Nicholson and Morgan Freeman, Reinerâ€™s latter-day directorial projects â€“ which included â€œBeing Charlie,â€ a family drama, rooted in autobiography â€” though eclectic as ever, seldom met with commercial favor.

	â€œIâ€™m making the movies I want to make,â€ he told the Guardian in 2008. â€œStudios are looking for hundreds and hundreds of millions of dollars in profit and youâ€™re not going to get it with a little movieâ€¦But I came into this business to express myself and tell stories, not just churn out a product.â€

	A prominent progressive voice in the Hollywood community, Reiner was active in several California ballot initiatives. He was an ardent supporter of Democratic candidates and a vocal opponent of President Donald Trump. In 2006, after contemplating a run against California governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, he decided to step away from the race.

	He was born March 6, 1947, in the New York borough of the Bronx. His father became one of the most prominent comedy writers and stars of the so-called â€œGolden Age of Television,â€ acting and writing on Sid Caesarâ€™s top-rated â€œYour Show of Showsâ€; he went on to create â€œThe Dick Van Dyke Showâ€ and direct a number of successful comedy features.

	The apple did not fall far from the tree. Raised in Hollywood, the younger Reiner attended UCLA Film School and began taking small roles in such TV shows as â€œBatman,â€ â€œThat Girl,â€ â€œThe Beverly Hillbilliesâ€ and â€œThe Partridge Family.â€ He also appeared in his fatherâ€™s autobiographical feature â€œEnter Laughingâ€ (1967).

	In 1971, Reiner was chosen, over such actors as Richard Dreyfuss and Harrison Ford, to play Archie Bunkerâ€™s put-upon son-in-law, opposite Sally Struthers as his wife Gloria, â€œAll in the Family,â€ creator Norman Learâ€™s Americanized version of the British sitcom â€œâ€˜Til Death Do Us Part.â€ The showâ€™s frank exploration of topical material previously considered too hot for TV and the great chemistry of the cast (which also included Jean Stapleton as Bunkerâ€™s wife Edith) made it a pivotal series in small-screen history.
	

	It took a few years for Reiner to find his footing after parting company with â€œAll in the Familyâ€ in 1978, but with his first major feature in 1984 he created an iconic musical comedy. Built on a roughly sketched treatment and essentially improvised in front of the camera, â€œThis is Spinal Tapâ€ introduced Christopher Guest, Michael McKean and Harry Shearer as the dim-witted members of the titular band, with Reiner portraying earnest doc director Marty DiBergi.

	Between 1986 and 1992, Reiner proved his versatility in a succession of films featuring strong performances. His work with the adolescent cast of â€œStand By Meâ€ earned him Golden Globe, Independent Spirit and DGA Award nominations. The offbeat â€œThe Princess Brideâ€ acquired a devoted cult following.

	His most assured directorial performance may have been â€œWhen Harry Met Sallyâ€¦,â€ which perfectly paired Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan as close friends who end up entering a romantic relationship. Written by Nora Ephron, the hit comedy featured an indelible sequence in which Ryan loudly demonstrates a fake orgasm for Crystal in a crowded restaurant; the sceneâ€™s unforgettable punchline, â€œIâ€™ll have what sheâ€™s having,â€ was delivered by the directorâ€™s mother Estelle.

	Reinerâ€™s box office track record began to cool in the late â€˜90s, as the writer-director increasingly pursued less commercial, more political subject matter, from the â€˜60s civil rights movement (â€œGhosts of Mississippi,â€ 1996) to the political career of Lyndon Johnson (â€œLBJ,â€ 2016) and the Gulf War of 2003 (â€œShock and Awe,â€ 2017).

	In 2023, he directed the documentary â€œAlbert Brooks: Defending My Life.â€

	One of the most outspoken of Hollywood political activists, Reiner eschewed office seeking in favor of work for his preferred causes, which encompassed gay rights advocacy and a protracted battle with the tobacco lobby.

	â€œNo, I donâ€™t want to be an elected official,â€ he said. â€œI want to get things done.â€

	Reiner and his wife are survived by children, Jake, Nick and Romy. He was the adoptive father of actress Tracy Reiner, the daughter of his first wife, the late actress and director Penny Marshall.

title: Rob Reiner Mourned by Hollywoodâ€™s Stunned A-List: â€˜We Lost One of the Few Good Menâ€™
description: Across Hollywood and beyond, celebrities and fans are paying tribute to director and actor Rob Reiner, who was found dead along with his wife Michel
body:
Across Hollywood and beyond, celebrities and fans are paying tribute to director and actor Rob Reiner, who was found dead along with his wife Michele on Sunday in their home. 

	The son of writer Carl Reiner, Rob Reiner first became known for his role as Meathead in the influential sitcom â€œAll in the Family.â€ He went on to direct classic films including â€œStand by Me,â€ â€œThis Is Spinal Tap,â€ â€œWhen Harry Met Sallyâ€¦â€ and â€œA Few Good Men.â€
	

	Christopher Guest, who starred in â€œThis Is Spinal Tap,â€ and his wife Jamie Lee Curtis said in a statement, â€œChristopher and I are numb and sad and shocked about the violent, tragic deaths of our dear friends Rob and Michelle Singer Reiner and our ONLY focus and care right now is for their children and immediate families and we will offer all support possible to help them.Â There will be plenty of time later to discuss the creative lives we shared and the great political and social impact they both had on the entertainment industry, early childhood development, the fight for gay marriage and their global care for a world in crisis. We have lost great friends. Please give us time to grieve.â€


	The late Norman Learâ€™s family wrote in a statement, â€œThe Lear Family is devastated by the deaths of Rob and Michele Reiner.Â Norman often referred to Rob as a son, and their close relationship was extraordinary,Â to us and the world. Norman would have wanted to remind us that Rob and Michele spent every breath trying to make this country a better place, and they pursued that through their art, their activism, their philanthropy, and their love for family and friends.Â  Lyn Lear had remained very close with them and said, â€˜The world is unmistakably darker tonight, and we are left bereft.'â€
	

	John Cusack, who starring in Reinerâ€™s film â€œThe Sure Thing,â€ wrote on Twitter â€œShocked by the death of Rob Reiner â€“ a great man.â€

	Barack Obama wrote, â€œTogether, he and his wife lived lives defined by purpose. They will be remembered for the values they championed and the countless people they inspired.â€

Michelle and I are heartbroken by the tragic passing of Rob Reiner and his beloved wife, Michele. Robâ€™s achievements in film and television gave us some of our most cherished stories on screen. But beneath all of the stories he produced was a deep belief in the goodness ofâ€¦â€” Barack Obama (@BarackObama) December 15, 2025


	Governor Gavin Newsom and his wife Jennifer Seibel Newsom said in a statement, â€œThat empathy extended well beyond his films. Rob was a passionate advocate for children and for civil rights â€” from taking on Big Tobacco to fighting for marriage equality to serving as a powerful voice in early education. He made California a better place through his good works.â€

	Director Paul Feig wrote, â€œRob was my true hero.â€

One of my most cherished pictures. Rob was my true hero. A true visionary titan and a lovely lovely person. One never knows if itâ€™s proper to post during something as tragic as this. But I just want the world to know what so many of us know in the industry. Rob was the best. ğŸ’” pic.twitter.com/oDn1FW1vqbâ€” Paul Feig (@paulfeig) December 15, 2025


	Sean Astin, president of SAG-AFTRA, saluted Reiner as a union member and pillar of the creative community for more than a half century.

	â€œRob Reiner is one of the most significant figures in the history of film and television. The impact he made on American culture simply canâ€™t be overstated. Tributes will pour in and the impossibly long list of genre defining films and indelible performances will play in our minds and hearts. Rob Reiner was a member of our union for nearly 60 years,â€ Astin said in a statement. â€œWe send love and warmth to Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reinerâ€™s families, friends and colleagues. Our entertainment community and audiences around the world will mourn deeply. On a personal note, so many of Mr. Reinerâ€™s films and performances made me think, made me emotional and especially they made me laugh really hard. Thatâ€™s how I will remember him.â€

	Reiner was a beloved figure in comedy circles, given his proud lineage and his indelible contributions to the form via such influential smashes as 1984â€™s â€œThis Is Spinal Tapâ€ and 1989â€™s â€œWhen Harry Met Sally.â€ Reiner was the son of Carl Reiner, who worked alongside Sid Caesar and Mel Brooks in the 1950s and â€™60s and went on to create â€œThe Dick Van Dyke Showâ€ and many other comedy projects. Rob Reiner proved his chops as an actor with the success of â€œAll in the Family,â€ which captured Americaâ€™s generation gap as the turbulent late 1960s gave way to the Me decade.
	

	â€œRob Reiner consistently worked from a place of conviction and integrity. Together, he and Michele were a force â€” combining comedy, creativity, and public engagement into their shared endeavors. They were as committed to making a difference as they were to their careers, a rare combination that makes this loss feel all the more profound,â€ said Journey Gunderson, executive director of the National Comedy Center in Jamestown, N.Y.  â€œWhen visiting us to pay tribute to his father, Rob did so with reverence, humility, kindness and a steadfast, enthusiastic intellect in matters of comedy and humanity. We are grateful to have known them both and for the impact they had on all of us.â€

	Reinerâ€™s hot streak as a helmer from the mid-1980s through mid-1990s is hard to top for movies that defined their eras. Fellow actors, writers and directors were quick to cite his films as seminal influences.

	Paul Walter Hauser wrote, â€œGrieving the loss of my favorite director of all-time. A Few Good Men is THE reason I became an actor, and Robâ€™s filmography behind the camera is THE reason I wanted to direct and still do.â€ The actor went on to share a story about the time he met Reiner.


	â€œHorrible. I didnâ€™t think today could get worse,â€ wrote Jon Cryer on Threads.

	Josh Gad wrote â€œRob Reiner and his wife Michelle were two of the most kind and caring souls you could ever imagine. He cared so much for those who had no voices.â€


	Actress Virginia Madsen wrote on Instagram â€œThank you Rob for giving us so much joy to hold on to. Life and talent always turned up to 11.â€


	Filmmaker Joe Russo wrote, â€œWe lost one of the few good men.â€


	Nancy Pelosi said, â€œRob was creative, funny, and beloved. And in all of their endeavors, Michelle was his indispensable partner, intellectual resource, and a loving wife.â€

The news of a deadly assault on Rob and Michelle Reiner in their home is devastating. Itâ€™s hard to think of anyone more remarkable and excellent in every field and endeavor they pursued. Rob was creative, funny, and beloved. And in all of their endeavors, Michelle was hisâ€¦â€” Nancy Pelosi (@SpeakerPelosi) December 15, 2025


This is a devastating loss for our city and our country. Rob Reinerâ€™s contributions reverberate throughout American culture and society, and he has improved countless lives through his creative work and advocacy fighting for social and economic justice. An acclaimed actor,â€¦â€” Mayor Karen Bass (@MayorOfLA) December 15, 2025


	See more reactions below:


Horrified to hear of the passing of Rob Reiner and his wonderful wife Michelle. So much love to their kids and family.â€” Elijah Wood (@elijahwood) December 15, 2025


Rob Reiner co-starred in one of the most influential sitcoms of all time, had an incredible run as a director â€” and was one of the kindest and most considerate human beings I've ever met in this business. RIP to Rob and to Michele. ğŸ™ğŸ» pic.twitter.com/qjNTfVfd0Yâ€” Richard Roeper (@RichardERoeper) December 15, 2025


Rest in peace Rob and Michele Reiner. Unrealâ€” Oâ€™Shea Jackson Jr (@OsheaJacksonJr) December 15, 2025


I am horrified and saddened at the tragic loss of one cinemaâ€™s greatest directors. I canâ€™t even begin to list the films this guy made that impacted me throughout my life. We all know them. A legend. A true genius.Rest in peace, Rob Reiner ğŸ’”https://t.co/cxQSqBBmptâ€” Bear McCreary ğŸ»ğŸ¶ (@bearmccreary) December 15, 2025

				Fans are mourning actor and director Rob Reiner, who was found dead Sunday with his wife.
Reiner made his mark as an actor on â€œAll in the Family,â€ probing the generation gap of the late 1960s with his role as liberal hippie Michael â€œMeatheadâ€ Stivic opposite Carroll Oâ€™Connorâ€™s blue-collar conservative Archie Bunker. Reiner then went on to direct such beloved 1980s and â€™90s films as â€œThis Is Spinal Tapâ€ (1984)Â  â€œStand By Meâ€ (1986), â€œThe Princess Brideâ€ (1987) and â€œWhen Harry Met Sallyâ€ (1989) and dramas â€œMiseryâ€ (1990) and â€œA Few Good Menâ€ (1992).
The seasoned Hollywood insider was active in state and national politics. He leveraged his celebrity status to advocate for universal preschool programs that became Californiaâ€™s First Five Initiative, and against Proposition 8, the state ballot initiative that sought to ban same sex marriage.
Look back at the distinguished career of the actor, writer and director who was part of a Hollywood dynasty as the son of Carl Reiner and singer-actress Estelle Reiner.

title: â€˜It: Welcome to Derryâ€™ Bosses on the Shocking Finale, the Future of Pennywise and That Post-Credits Scene That Ties It All Together
description:
SPOILER ALERT:Â This story contains spoilers from the Season 1 finale of â€œIt: Welcome to Derry,â€ now streaming on HBO Max.

	The first season of â€œIt:
body:
SPOILER ALERT:Â This story contains spoilers from the Season 1 finale of â€œIt: Welcome to Derry,â€ now streaming on HBO Max.

	The first season of â€œIt: Welcome to Derryâ€ concluded in a way that was truly thrilling and chilling, with the showâ€™s full ensemble taking on Pennywise the Clown (Bill SkarsgÃ¥rd) as he covered the titular town in an icy, supernatural fog. While series creators Barbara and Andy Muschietti insist that the climaxâ€™s liminal environment was not an intentional nod to Stephen Kingâ€™s â€œThe Mist,â€ they acknowledge the overlap in the universe, which is full of references to other King works such as â€œThe Shiningâ€ and â€œThe Shawshank Redemption.â€
	

	In the spirit of the authorâ€™s expansive source material, the brother-sister director-producer duo also note that Pennywiseâ€™s story is not over. Even though â€œWelcome to Derryâ€ is a prequel to their 2017 and 2019 films, itâ€™s already been established that the evil spirit possessing Pennywise arrived in Derry several generations ago, and the finale alludes to the antagonistic clownâ€™s atemporal reality. Though they couldnâ€™t give much away, the Muschiettis confirmed that they intend for a Season 2 to take place in 1935, chronicling the previous cycle of Pennywiseâ€™s awakening in the town. (HBO has not yet officially renewed â€œWelcome to Derry.â€)


	The overlapping timelines were made evident in the finaleâ€™s post-credit scene, which flash-forwards to 1988, showing Beverly Marsh (Sophia Lillis) briefly before the events of the first â€œItâ€ film, previewing the tragedy that would set her own battle with Pennywise in motion. The scene features an elderly version of Madeleine Stoweâ€™s character, Ingrid Kersh, revealing her to actually be the same old woman that It manifests as in â€œIt: Chapter 2â€ to haunt the grown-up Marsh (Jessica Chastain). 91 year-old-actress Joan Gregson reprised her role as the elderly Mrs. Kersh for the scene. 
	

	Variety spoke with Andy and Barbara Muschietti â€”Â and emailed with co-showrunner, executiveÂ producer and co-creator Jason Fuchs â€” to talk about the seasonâ€™s climactic finale, the seriesâ€™ future and the post-credit scene that tied it all together.
	
		Going into the finale, what questions did you know you wanted to answer to conclude Season 1?	

	Jason Fuchs: There were certain mysteries that had to be answered. Why does It remain in Derry? Well, now we know: he is trapped there within the cage assembled by the Children of Maturin centuries ago. Why does It choose the form of Pennywise? We know that now, too: itâ€™s a real-life clown that the entity encountered in 1908. He saw the way children reacted to Bob Grayâ€™s on-stage persona, almost like a hypnotic Pied Piper effect and decided, â€œWait, this is a manifestation I can use to lure kids in.â€ And I also think it was important to understandÂ the story of Ingrid Kersh. We have a fairly complete understanding of how Bob Grayâ€™s daughter, after losing her father as a child, encounters this manifestation of him in 1935 and has been, in essence, operating as Itâ€™s â€œfamiliarâ€ ever since to keep seeing what she thinks is a form of her father.Â 
	
		Was it always the plan to have the season end with this climactic battle in the fog?	

	Andy Muschietti: No. I think we were in production already and we decided that the Dagger would be a more prominent element in the story. This ending was molded and shaped along the way, but once we decided the episodeâ€™s big story would be about returning the Dagger to the dead pine, we had an idea. We really wanted a photo-finish moment, though, because there is so much anxiety in the sequence. Thatâ€™s when I thought of bringing back Richie [Arian S. Cartaya]. Because we are in a world where people can see dead people, we thought it would be perfect for him to come back and help the other kids put the dagger back into the ground.



	

	


	
		Was the idea of the fog over Derry taken from the novel?	

	Andy Muschietti: No, not at all. Thereâ€™s a lot of stuff that we invented for the show, but from our first conversations with Stephen King, he was on board with us creating a lot.
	
	
		I thought it might be an allusion to his novella, â€œThe Mistâ€?	

	Andy Muschietti: Itâ€™s not, but of course, in â€œThe Mist,â€ they say that the mist comes from the Todash Field, the same interdimensional plane that It is from. So itâ€™s unrelated, but itâ€™s also related. I wanted to use the fog to visually illustrate the expansion of the clouds that surround the Dead Lights. When we see the meteor crash into Derry in Episode 4, we see the three Dead Lights dancing around this cloud of fog. The physical element is established there, and for this story, I wanted to show that it is an expansive force.
	
		How did you create that environment from a physical production standpoint?	

	Barbara Muschietti: Part of why we had to transition to this frozen world was because of the strikes. Filming went from Fall to Winter, so the setting had to match that. We thought of going to a real location in Ontario, but that thought lasted about a second and a half. We did a lot of November nights in Ontario on our first film, â€œMama,â€ and that is not something we wanted to repeat or put our actors through again. So we made a conscious decision to go on a stage. Andy then gave it a real magical feel, working with our production designer Paul Austerberry and our DP Danny Vilar and our special effects crew to mist the whole stage for days and days.
	
		How many days did it take to shoot?	

	Barbara Muschietti: We went back and forth. We were trying to keep some days as weather cover, but it was weeks.

	Andy Muschietti: It was a mess, but it was brought into shape by our first AD, Joanna Moore, who is an absolute genius. The challenge was shooting on a stage and making it look like an outdoor space of undetermined size. We were doing all kinds of cheating, expanding distances, shooting on one corner of the set to get more distance from the other corner. VFX did a great job to make cohesion of all those different fragments.
	
		Did you have just one unit, or did you use a second unit?	

	Andy Muschietti: We had a second unit for specific shots that didnâ€™t require cast performances and some fights that required stunts. There were times where we were splitting the shoot with other scenes. It was a mess, but it was a lot of fun.

	Barbara Muschietti: It was the end of Andyâ€™s block, which meant he wouldnâ€™t be shooting anymore afterwards. When Andy knows the end is coming, his brain goes into overdrive and he starts thinking of new stuff and the pressure is on. Thatâ€™s the way Andy and I work. Sometimes we have four cameras on set shooting completely different set-ups. Itâ€™s chaotic, but we have a great team who welcomes this and everything ends up getting done.

	Andy Muschietti: Yeah, in spite of having been there for months, the crew was really engaged with the story. Thatâ€™s not a given. These guys were phenomenal.
	
	
		The climax was also the first scene with the entire cast together, including Bill SkarsgÃ¥rdâ€™s Pennywise. What was it like directing everyone together?	

	Andy Muschietti: It was challenging because of the geography. There are three or four different groups of people in the scene. The challenge was establishing the geography at every turn of the story so people would understand whatâ€™s going on, and where people are in relation to things and each other, all in an environment where the characters canâ€™t see each other. There was a lot of preparation. We drew a lot of little maps.



	

									Photo: Brooke Palmer
	


	
		The finale also makes some allusions to things to come. Pennywise talks about the future and the past and Margy suggests that he may be able to travel through time. Youâ€™ve mentioned that youâ€™re going to make two more seasons that go in the reverse chronology of Pennywiseâ€™s 27-year cycles. Is this still the plan?	

	Andy Muschietti: Yeah, that was always the plan from the beginning. Our first pitch to Stephen King was to tell the story backwards. I canâ€™t say too much about the logic behind it, because I donâ€™t want to spoil it, but it has to do with how Pennywise experiences time in a non-linear way. We sort of hinted at it at the end of the season.
	
		Have you already started writing it?	

	Barbara Muschietti: We canâ€™t talk about it.
	

	Andy Muschietti: We can only say the stuff thatâ€™s already known, like itâ€™s in 1935, 27 years before Season 1 and it involves the massacre of the Bradley Gang from the books. It takes place during the Depression in Derry, and there are some new characters and some characters from this season as well, but younger versions of them.
	
		Viewers know that Pennywise lives into the future, though, since weâ€™ve seen him in the â€œItâ€ movies. Did that present a unique challenge, since we know that Pennywise doesnâ€™t die in this finale?	

	Jaon Fuchs: Prequels always present a unique challenge in terms of stakes, in that the audience already knows the fate of key characters. In this case, we know It survives our show because It is still around eating kids in 1989 and beyond. So, it was an early conversation with Andy about, okay, well how do we create real stakes? Yes, we are going to create stakes in the context of â€œWe care about these characters and what happens to them,â€ but how do we elevate the stakes of this beyond your traditional prequel? And the answer to that is not fully explained within the season, but there is certainly a hint of it in our finale. When It reveals the missing poster of Richie Tozier, from â€œChapter 1,â€ and has this admission that the past, present and future are all a bit jumbled, that moment is establishing a new mystery and that mystery is directly linked to raising the stakes of the series. Because ifÂ It has this, letâ€™s say, unique relationship with or to the perception of time, that suggests that the restrictions on what can happen in a prequel may or may not apply in the context of our particular story. Maybe It, in this show, is more dangerous we understood.



	

	


	
		Speaking of overlapping timelines, Season 1 ends with a post-credits flash-forward where we see Sophia Lillis reprising her role as Beverly Marsh from the films and encountering an elderly Mrs. Kersh, who is the old lady from â€œChapter 2.â€ Did you always expect to have this scene at the end of Season 1?	

	Andy Muschietti: No, we didnâ€™t think of it until we were doing reshoots and pick-ups before the edit.

	Barbara Muschietti: This was April of this year, so not long ago at all.
	

	Andy Muschietti: I had a notion of what the show was going to look like, but I still wanted a visual connection to the characters from the movies. I had an idea for a four-scene epilogue, but it was a little too ambitious, so we condensed it to one scene with just one of the Losers. We always joke that Sophia Lillis always looks the same. She looked 14 when she was 14 and now that sheâ€™s 24, she still looks 14, so we could bring her back without having to de-age her. We also brought back the actress who plays the elderly Ingrid Kersh, Joan Gregson, in â€œIt: Chapter 2.â€ We wanted to show that those characters had met before, so in the flash-forward, we have Kersh still committed at Juniper Hill, the same place where Beverlyâ€™s mom was committed. It seemed like the perfect connection.

	Jason Fuchs: What I love about that scene is that it does change your understanding of Beverlyâ€™s encounter with Itâ€™s manifestation of Mrs. Kersh in â€œIt: Chapter 2.â€ I was lucky enough to work on that scene and, at the time, I imagined that It was taking the guise of Pennywiseâ€™s daughter in order to prey on Beverlyâ€™s traumatic relationship with her own father. It did not, then, occur to me that Beverly Marsh had ever met the realÂ Mrs. Kersh. But now, you go back and rewatch that scene and you realize It was up to something else. It knows that Beverly actually met Mrs. Kersh at least once and it was on the worst day of her life, the day her mother committed suicide. So, when It takes that form, itâ€™s also a way of tapping into a long buried memory thatâ€™s intertwined with the most horrific moment, to that point, of Beverlyâ€™s young life. And thatâ€™s the day, the moment, we get to see at the end of our season.Â 

	Barbara Muschietti: What sparked it was our cameraman mentioning that he recently worked with Joan. When Joan played Mrs. Kersh in 2018, she was 85 years old, so now she was 91.

	Andy Muschietti: And she did everything at 85. She did nudity, full frontal, and was phenomenal, but we didnâ€™t know if she was still acting or anything.

	Barbara Muschietti: But when we heard that she was, the idea for the scene came to Andy. We didnâ€™t have any money left, but it was so important to Andy that we sat down with the budget and cut some VFX from the show so we could shoot the scene. Then we called Sophia, who is an absolute queen. She got on a plane right away, and we got to shoot this incredible scene that connects the show and the movies.

	Andy Muschietti: I really want to thank Barbara publicly now, because I remember that moment when I wanted to shoot the scene and Barbara bent the iron bar in a way that normally would have been impossible to do with the budget and time we had. Thank you.

	Barbara Muschietti: Youâ€™re welcome! I enjoyed it very much and we had to shoot very fast. Joan was having so much fun, just laughing, smiling, crying in all the different takes. She left us two months later.

	Andy Muschietti: Yeah, this was her last role.

	Barbara Muschietti: She was a revered Canadian actress who did theater all her life, so we feel very blessed. It gave everything a bit of closure.

	This interview has been edited and condensed.

body:
George Clooney is no longer interested in romance on the big screen.

	During a recent interview with the Daily Mail, Clooney said that after having a discussion with his wife, Amal Clooney, about his age, he will no longer be â€œkissing girlsâ€ in movies.

	â€œIâ€™ve been trying to go the route Paul Newman did â€” â€˜Okay, well, Iâ€™m not kissing a girl anymore,â€™â€ Clooney said.


	He added, â€œWhen I turned 60, I had a conversation with my wife. I said, â€˜Look, I can still play basketball with the boys. I play with 25-year-old guys. I can still hang, Iâ€™m in shape. But in 25 years, Iâ€™m 85 years old. It doesnâ€™t matter how many granola bars you eat, thatâ€™s a real number.'â€
	

	Clooney made his career as one of Hollywoodâ€™s most popular romantic leads. Some of his credits include romance films like â€œOne Fine Dayâ€ with Michelle Pfeiffer, â€œOut of Sightâ€ with Jennifer Lopez, â€œUp in the Airâ€ with Vera Farmiga and â€œTicket to Paradiseâ€ with Julia Roberts.

	The â€œOceanâ€™s Elevenâ€ star may have been hinting at this decision for a while. He told â€œ60 Minutesâ€ back in March that he was stepping away from â€œromantic filmsâ€ entirely to make room for Hollywoodâ€™s new crop of leading men.

	â€œLook, Iâ€™m 63 years old. Iâ€™m not trying to compete with 25-year-old leading men,â€ he said. â€œThatâ€™s not my job. Iâ€™m not doing romantic films anymore.â€

	In a 2022 sitdown with the New York Times, Clooney recalled that even early in his career, he had trouble with a director who criticized his on-screen kissing technique.

	Clooney said, â€œI remember early on in my career, I had to do a kissing scene with this girl and the director goes, â€˜Not like that.â€™ And I was like, â€˜Dude, thatâ€™s my move! Thatâ€™s what I do in real life!â€™â€

title: LAPD Investigates Deaths of Rob Reiner and Wife: â€˜No One Has Been Detainedâ€™
description: Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were found dead at their Brentwood home on Sunday in an apparent homicide, Variety has confirmed.
body:
Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were found dead at their Brentwood home on Sunday in an apparent homicide, Variety has confirmed.

	â€œIt is with profound sorrow that we announce the tragic passing of Michele and Rob Reiner,â€ a family spokesman said in a statement. â€œWe are heartbroken by this sudden loss, and we ask for privacy during this unbelievably difficult time.â€

	The LAPD responded to the home at 3:40 p.m. and discovered two deceased victims. The LAPD described the deaths as â€œan apparent homicide,â€ but did not confirm the victimsâ€™ identities. ABC7 reported that the victims appeared to have been stabbed.
	

	A family member close to the Reiners was being questioned by authorities, law enforcement sources told the Los Angeles Times.

	â€œWe have not identified a suspect at this time,â€ said Deputy Chief Alan Hamilton at a press conference Sunday night. â€œNo one has been detained.â€

	Hamilton also said the detectives had canvassed the neighborhood, but â€œare not looking for anyoneâ€ in Brentwood.

	Detectives from the LAPD Robbery Homicide Division responded to the home to conduct the investigation. Hamilton said the detectives would have to obtain a search warrant before going inside.

	Karen Bass, the mayor of Los Angeles, mourned Reinerâ€™s death in a statement, calling it â€œa devastating loss for our city and our country.â€

	â€œThe investigation is ongoing,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™m holding all who loved Rob and Michele in my heart.â€

	Hamilton said police expected to update the press again on Monday morning.

	Reiner is a major filmmaker who comes from a storied Hollywood family. His father is comedian and director Carl Reiner. Reinerâ€™s films include such classics as â€œThis Is Spinal Tap,â€ â€œThe Princess Bride,â€ â€œStand By Me,â€ â€œMisery,â€ â€œWhen Harry Met Sallyâ€¦â€ and â€œThe American President.â€ A prominent progressive voice in the Hollywood community, Reiner is active in several California ballot initiatives, as well as acts as a major fundraiser for the Democratic Party. He has been a major critic of President Donald Trump.
	

	Before moving behind the camera, Reiner also starred as Michael â€œMeatheadâ€ Stivic, hippie son-in-law of Carroll Oâ€™Connorâ€™s bigoted, blustering blue-collar worker Archie Bunker, during nine seasons of â€œAll in the Family.â€ Reiner co-founded Castle Rock, the production company behind hits such as â€œIn the Line of Fireâ€ and â€œCity Slickers,â€ the critically acclaimed drama â€œThe Shawshank Redemption,â€ and â€œSeinfeld.â€

	Singer was at one time a photographer who shot Donald Trumpâ€™s photo for the cover of â€œThe Art of the Deal.â€ The couple have three children â€” Jake, Nick and Romy. He is the adoptive father of actress Tracy Reiner, the daughter of his first wife, the late actress and director Penny Marshall.

title: Rian Johnson Says He Has â€˜Conceptual Ideasâ€™ For Fourth â€˜Knives Outâ€™ Movie: â€˜Itâ€™d Be Interesting If it Were This Kind of Thingâ€™
description: Rian Johnsonâ€˜s â€œWake Up Dead Man,â€ the third film in the Daniel Craig-starring â€œKnives Outâ€ murder mystery series, just arrived on Netflix on Dec. 1
body:
Rian Johnsonâ€˜s â€œWake Up Dead Man,â€ the third film in the Daniel Craig-starring â€œKnives Outâ€ murder mystery series, just arrived on Netflix on Dec. 12. However, the director already has thoughts about the next installment in the franchise. Johnson told Entertainment Weekly, â€œI have some basic, elemental, conceptual ideas. Like, â€˜Okay, itâ€™d be interesting if it were this kind of thingâ€™ kernels.â€

	The director continued, â€œI donâ€™t have actual concrete ideas. I donâ€™t have a theme yet. I donâ€™t have a location. Itâ€™s really pretty vague, and I feel like itâ€™s good to kinda keep it vague until Iâ€™m ready to actually sit down and write it.â€
	

	In the meantime, Johnson hopes to direct at least one original film before returning to â€œKnives Outâ€ for another story of Craigâ€™s stately southern detective Benoit Blanc. He says that the â€œKnives Outâ€ movies are all meant to be products of their time, and therefore, the intricate plots and their surrounding themes cannot be rushed.

	â€œPart of making these movies, for me, is reacting to the present moment, not necessarily with current events or politics or culture specifically, but in terms of what weâ€™re all feeling in the world at that moment,â€ Johnson said. â€œI like that these movies are not timeless, per se, and that they all have one foot in something that is common to all of us in our present moment. So, yeah, I donâ€™t know. I have a vague notion, but trying to keep it vague until itâ€™s time to actually do it.â€

	Johnson began the â€œKnives Outâ€ series in 2019, with Lionsgateâ€™s release of the first film in theaters. Netflix subsequently acquired the rights for two sequels to the original and released the second installment, â€œGlass Onionâ€ in 2022. â€œWake Up Dead Manâ€ had its world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival in September and was released in select theaters on Nov. 26.

title: â€˜Landmanâ€™ Star Jacob Lofland on Cooperâ€™s Risky Choices and Learning From â€˜Polite and Humbleâ€™ Legends Like Billy Bob Thornton and Sam Elliott
description: SPOILER ALERT:Â This post contains light spoilers from Season 2, Episode 5 of â€œLandman,â€ â€œThe Pirate Dinner,â€ which premiered Sunday, Dec. 14, on Par
body:
SPOILER ALERT:Â This post contains light spoilers from Season 2, Episode 5 of â€œLandman,â€ â€œThe Pirate Dinner,â€ which premiered Sunday, Dec. 14, on Paramount+.

	Acting on â€œLandmanâ€ is a dream job for Jacob Lofland, but there was one unique challenge for him as an artist. He plays Cooper Norris, the son of Tommy, who is the center of the seriesâ€™ universe. But while everyone else in his onscreen family is always dressed in their southern best, it is often remarked that Cooper â€”Â who is frequently toiling at the oil fields â€” smells bad or needs a shower and deodorant. It eventually made Lofland paranoid that show co-creator Taylor Sheridan, who also writes every episode, might be trying to say something about his hygiene.
	

	â€œI got self-conscious of that at some point,â€ Lofland says, laughing. â€œI would walk around after about three times last season of hearing that, going, â€˜You know, I donâ€™t think Iâ€™m that bad. Have I just been around Taylor and somethingâ€™s not smelling good?â€™ But I think it goes back to the character, and he just spends so much time out in the patch, and itâ€™s 100 degrees out there at all times. Thereâ€™s not enough deodorant in the world to keep these guys from smelling like theyâ€™re going to smell. Not to mention it, oil and gas donâ€™t smell amazing anyway, so thereâ€™s always sulfur in the air. Iâ€™m really hoping thatâ€™s where itâ€™s coming from.â€


	This season, Cooper is getting more scrutiny for his life choices than his scent. The ambitious young man is taking some big swings, perhaps without giving them enough thought. In this episode, Cooper and Tommy have a lunch filled with straight talk. By the end, Cooper is selling his lucky-strike oil sites to his fatherâ€™s company, after Tommy makes it clear that his sonâ€™s new business partner, Gallino (Andy Garcia), will bleed him dry. Luckily, Tommy rewards his sonâ€™s instincts by also offering him a job at M-Tex.
	

	Unfortunately, Tommy doesnâ€™t have as much luck talking Cooper out of quickly marrying Ariana (Paulina Chavez), despite their fraught relationship.

	Lofland says that while Cooperâ€™s decisions might frustrate the audience, his impulsiveness is an important part of what makes the character tick.

	â€œThe reason I really fell in love with this character is that it is relatable for the age and for what heâ€™s going through at that time,â€ he says. â€œIâ€™m a little older than Cooper; Iâ€™m 29 now, so I would make a few different decisions. But Iâ€™ve also made those mistakes when I was younger. Different businesses, different things, but definitely jumped off in stuff when I didnâ€™t know what I was doing. So Iâ€™ve learned that lesson over the years, and I think itâ€™s important for him to go through that time in life, make these decisions, screw up, learn from the mistakes, donâ€™t do it again.â€

	In terms of Loflandâ€™s personal growth, he says working opposite Thornton shows him what it means to be a leader on a production.

	â€œItâ€™s so fun â€”Â he makes it easy,â€ Lofland says. â€œHe shows up every day, and Billy is our Number One. So on any set, your Number One sets the pace and the attitude for everybody else. Billy shows up every day ready to work and excited about the job, which in turn makes everyone else excited. It just trickles down.â€

	This season also introduces Sam Elliott as Cooperâ€™s grandfather, and gives Lofland another veteran actor heâ€™s happy to model his on-set conduct after.

	â€œThe one thing Iâ€™ve learned is itâ€™s never a conversation that you learn from,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s just being able to be around these men and women that have done this for so long, and watch the way they carry themselves, the way they work, their ethic and their attitude. I think that teaches more and speaks more than any piece of advice they could ever give. Sam and Billy, theyâ€™re so prepared, so professional. You never wait on them. Theyâ€™re never the reason that weâ€™re running three minutes behind. Everyoneâ€™s ready to go, and theyâ€™re so polite and humble, willing to work through and take the time. If there are questions or a sceneâ€™s not going the way we feel it should, letâ€™s sit down and talk about it. Itâ€™s a team effort. Those guys are so good at that, thatâ€™s probably the most impactful thing for me.â€
	

	As for the rest of the season, Lofland encourages fans to expect the unexpected in Cooperâ€™s storyline.

	â€œThereâ€™s definitely going to be some growth, but Iâ€™ll tell you, there are a few things coming up that no one sees,â€ he says. â€œThere are some twists and turns and surprises that I donâ€™t think anyoneâ€™s predicted yet. I canâ€™t wait for the world to see it.â€

	SPOILER ALERT:Â This post contains spoilers from Season 2, Episode 5 of â€œLandman,â€ â€œThe Pirate Dinner,â€ which premiered Sunday, Dec. 14, on Paramount+.

	At one point in this weekâ€™s episode of â€œLandman,â€ Tommy (Billy Bob Thornton) gets so frustrated that he starts hitting his truck. It makes sense! His son Cooper (Jacob Lofland) is making some really reckless decisions in both his personal and professional life; his father, T.L. (Sam Elliott), is moving in; he is being left out of business decisions by his team; and Angela (Ali Larter) is planning another themed dinner. Will Tommy be able to help keep his family and business in order? Find out with this weekâ€™s recap.
	


Oops, already crying at happy T.L., looking at the sunset at Tommyâ€™s nice house by the pool.
â€œâ€˜Til he dies.â€ Oh, Tommy, such a way with words.
Nate (Colm Feore), stop trying to throw T.L. out of the house! No one asked you!
Angela just wants to have a good time and throw parties! Let her live.
Ooh, what does barbecued blue crab taste like? It sounds delicious.
Why does Tommy suddenly know the etymology of â€œbuccaneersâ€?
â€œGulf of America now, baby.â€ â€œI donâ€™t give a fuck what they call it.â€Â Will MAGA viewers get rocked by WOKE TOMMY?
Uh oh, Cooper acting rich before he gets a check is a big red flag.
Why canâ€™t Ariana (Paulina Chavez) give Cooper her dadâ€™s address? Is a scavenger hunt part of a Catholic proposal?
Oh my gosh, Cooper is so screwed. Iâ€™m stressed.
Tommy is being mighty generous to Cooper by bringing him on board. Will his instincts prove to be just blind luck?
â€œIf she swallowed a lump of coal, sheâ€™d make a diamond in three daysâ€ is a great folksy description of a wound-up person.
You know Tommyâ€™s frustrated when he repeatedly assaults his dependable truck.
Love these always-rowdy elders at the retirement home. Theyâ€™re really concerned about Angelaâ€™s sex life!
Phew, MAGA folks will feel welcome again now that Tommy described â€œThe Viewâ€ as â€œA bunch of pissed-off millionaires bitching about how much they hate millionaires and Trump and men and you and me and everybody else they got a bee up their ass about.â€
Itâ€™d be kind of great to see T.L. kick Tommyâ€™s ass. I could definitely see it happening!
â€œYou got a cool voice.â€ Love the respect for Elliott.
Damn, is T.L. flirting with Shelby (Audrey McGraw)? They should hook up!
Wow, Rebecca (Kayla Wallace) and M-Tex just got screwed so quickly in that meeting. Their lenders arenâ€™t fucking around anymore!
â€œWell, thatâ€™s not what your boss says. She says you need a partner pretty bad.â€ Oof, Gallino (Andy Garcia) knows just how to twist the knife in Tommy.
Who knew that Gallino was a putting phenom?
Aww, itâ€™s so nice to see T.L. getting a kick out of Angela and Ainsley (Michelle Randolph). Theyâ€™re fun!
The bandage on Alan (Jim Meskimen) is a great callback to Episode 3â€™s incident at the Cattlemenâ€™s Club.
â€œIâ€™ll win this, too.â€ Uh oh, Cami (Demi Moore)â€¦youâ€™re being a bit cavalier about a cartel.
Wow, it was tough to see Cami check Tommy so deliberately. â€œDonâ€™t ever summon me to a meeting again.â€ To be fair, Tommy did tell her to toughen up when taking over the company!
Oh, OK: I guess Cooper getting permission to marry Ariana wasnâ€™t that big of a deal. Crisis averted!
Damn, Tommy lost both his sense of smell and taste when he was 30? No wonder heâ€™s a grump!
Angela killed it with the Pirate Dinner. No notes.
Big laugh with Rebeccaâ€™s pirate outfit.
Even Tommyâ€™s laughing and having fun. Great end to the episode!



	Until next week, describe what youâ€™d wear to Angelaâ€™s Pirate Dinner in the comments.



	
		More from Variety

title: All-American Rejects Stop Show Mid-Song to Aid Fainting Fan
description:
All-American Rejects
                          Medical Scare Halts Concert
body:
All-American Rejects
                          Medical Scare Halts Concert
                      
      
    
      
        
                    
                  
      
                    TMZ.com
          
    
          A medical scare briefly stopped the show at KROQ's Almost Acoustic Christmas when All-American Rejects frontman, Tyson Ritter, abruptly cut the band's finale mid-song to help a fan who collapsed in the crowd.
      
    
          TMZ has obtained video showing the band halfway through "Gives You Hell" inside the packed L.A. Kia Forum, when Ritter suddenly halted the music, grabbed the mic, and pointed toward the pit, alerting security that a woman had passed out and needed help.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          In front of thousands, Ritter calmly told the crowd to open space and assist her, then added a little holiday improv, urging someone to get the woman "Twinkies or sugar or Christmas gumdrops or pieces of gingerbread houses" to help her. Ritter also called out, "Are you okay?," checking on her from the stage.
      

          Once the woman was safely removed from the crowd and the situation settled, Ritter jumped back into the chorus and finished the song.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          The emergency became one of the night's unexpected highlights at the annual holiday concert, which delivered a stacked lineup featuring Third Eye Blind, Evanescence, Papa Roach, Yellowcard, Social Distortion, and Rise Against.
      
    
          And in classic Almost Acoustic fashion, the crowd got one last gift ... a surprise performance from 4 Non Blondes.

title: Police to Release Person of Interest in Brown University Mass Shooting
description:
Brown University Shooting
                          Police Releasing Person Of Interest
body:
Brown University Shooting
                          Police Releasing Person Of Interest
                          ... Cite Insufficient Evidence
                      
                  
                                                                        Published 
                              December 14, 2025
                            5:38 PM PST
                                                                      |
                                                                Updated 
                                  December 14, 2025
                                9:05 PM PST
                                    
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Update
  
    
          8:40 PM PT -- In a major twist ... Authorities are releasing the person of interest in the Brown University mass shooting because they had "some degree of evidence" against him, but the "evidence now points in a different direction," according to Rhode Island Attorney General Peter Neronha.
      
    
          The person of interest taken into custody in connection to the Brown University shooting is reportedly a 24-year-old with U.S. Army training.
      
    
          CNN -- citing multiple law enforcement sources -- has identified the person of interest as Benjamin Erickson ... a man from Wisconsin who served in the army from 2021 to 2024, according to his LinkedIn profile, which has been taken down.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Erickson reportedly passed sniper training, worked in firearms instruction and ultimately left the miltiary after having attained the rank of "specialist."
      

          A spokesperson for the U.S. Army told the outlet he was never deployed ... and his social media indicates he served at Arlington National Cemetery.
      
    
      
        
                    
                  
      
                    Providence Police Department
          
    
          As you know ... a person of interest was taken into custody Sunday morning at a Rhode Island hotel where he was reportedly found with a pair of firearms.
      
    
          The POI's detention came after authorities released video of the suspect fleeing the scene ... making a sharp turn around a corner and keeping his head down in his all black outfit.
      
    
          2 people were killed and 8 more were injured after Saturday's shooting which took place in a building on the school's campus. The shooting sparked a massive police response and has led to vigils in the Providence area.
